article.title: The metallicity and star formation activity of long gamma-ray burst hosts for z$<$3: insights from the Illustris simulation

multiple_choice_question.text: What does the green line in Figure 1 represent?
choices: The cosmic star formation rate density for all stellar populations in the Illustris simulation.
The observed cosmic star formation rate density compiled by Behroozi et al. (2013).
The cosmic star formation rate density for stellar populations with metallicity below 0.1 Z⊙ in the Illustris simulation.
The intrinsic long gamma-ray burst rate for a metallicity threshold of 0.1 Z⊙.

multiple_choice_question.text: What is the main conclusion drawn from Figure 2 regarding the mass-metallicity relation of LGRB host galaxies?
choices: Simulated LGRB hosts follow the mass-metallicity relation intrinsic to the Illustris simulation, but a metallicity threshold is required to match observations.
Simulated LGRB hosts with no metallicity threshold provide a good match to observed LGRB hosts in terms of the mass-metallicity relation.
Simulated LGRB hosts show a clear offset towards lower metallicities compared to the observed mass-metallicity relation of field galaxies.
The Illustris simulation fails to reproduce the observed mass-metallicity relation of both LGRB host galaxies and field galaxies.
The probability of a galaxy with a given stellar mass to host an LGRB.
The intrinsic cosmic LGRB rate as a function of redshift, assuming LGRB progenitors are massive stars with a minimum mass Mmin.
The metallicity threshold for the formation of LGRB progenitors.
The internal metallicity dispersion of a galaxy as a function of its average metallicity.

multiple_choice_question.text: What trend is observed in Figure 9 regarding the internal metallicity dispersion (σz) of LGRB host galaxies as a function of their average metallicity?
choices: There is no correlation between σz and average metallicity, regardless of the assumed metallicity threshold for LGRB progenitors.
σz decreases with increasing average metallicity for all metallicity thresholds.
A correlation between σz and average metallicity emerges as the metallicity threshold for LGRB progenitors becomes more stringent (lower Zth).
The simulated σz values are significantly lower than the model proposed by Niino et al. (2016) for all metallicity thresholds.
